TopicTitle: The "You know you're playing a lot of KSP when..." thread

Articles.Content: I keep trying to convert my car's gas gauge into delta-V, and thinking of highway on-ramps as Hohmann transfers. >_>
Yeah I keep trying to rotate pictures...
When you see circular red lights on the car in front and the first thing that springs to mind is "Ion Engines".
When you balance out your shopping in the trunk so it is symmetrical.
When you press "M" to get out of the slideshow-reading mode in microsoft powerpoint
When you only ever buy Orbit chewing gum. (it's the cheapest one around here, too!)
You know you play too much KSP when you forget to check for updates because you are obsessed with getting to Eeloo. (Happened to me. I was still at .20 and the game was at .23)

When you have finally stopped having all those silly fantasies and daydreams. You know the ones, where you are going out with friends, watching sports, sleeping, eating, paying bills, having a few pints...

When you only ever buy Orbit chewing gum. (it's the cheapest one around here, too!)

I would think Beeman's would also be appropriate.

One night, during the point where I was still learning about how to work with orbital mechanics, I stayed up late playing KSP.

The next morning I was woken up because family members wanted my chauffeur services. For a few moments I was just babbling about how there wasn't any point in burning at that point. "we gotta wait until we reach periapsis, otherwise we will just be wasting fuel!". I assume I must have had a pretty intense dream about the interstices of orbital maneuvering.

I then realized that a car is not a rocket, roads are not space, and driving on them does not have anything to do with orbital mechanics.

Edited January 25, 2014 by maccollo
When you are on a plane and think "This plane has enough fuel to go to space, why aren't we going to space?!"
When you start saying things like disney world escape in 4 minutes
...When you try to save your Word documents with f5 and then your computer flips and a window pops up.
When watching a documentary on the ISS I found myself wondering if its part count caused much lag.
You're travelling somewhere, and when you're halfway to your destination you assume that the other half will take less time because of gravity.
When you zoom out in Google Earth and expect to see the Moon orbiting around the planet.

It's probably been mentioned a few times, but the kerbal-themed dreams of orbital mechanics and interplanetary travel are pretty fun.

I'm also really noticing the lack of orbital mechanics in the fiction I enjoy. It's slightly immersion breaking, but I still love those other games and films/shows.
...when you aerobrake in your car.
When you go to bed and build rockets while you're in a lucid dream.

...when you aerobrake in your car.

Fixed that for you:

When you aerolithobrake your car.
When you try to plan a free return trajectory to the grocery store
You perceive normal speed stuff as something sped up. Because you play with large ships...
Your ships are always perfect first time out...then you wake up.

Fixed that for you:

When you aerolithobrake your car.

Let me fix that for you

When you areolithohydrobrake your car.

Lemme fix that one more time:

When you <strike>aerolithohydrobrake</strike> encounter the Kraken in your car.
